episode.content: When the autumn leaves are at their finest, a huge tent village pops up in a valley in the Northern Alps in Nagano Prefecture. At night, lights inside these seemingly countless tents give off a colorful glow. Among the campers is a group of coworkers who usually hit bars in the city but traveled all the way for a drinking-party with a difference, and a man who dreamed of sleeping in a tent with his young daughter. Each tent pitched on the rocky ground at an altitude of 2,300 meters is there for a unique reason. For 3 days, we spoke to the people seeking something "a little different" under the starry sky.
episode.description: Each autumn, a tent village pops up in a picturesque valley in Japan's Northern Alps. The reasons campers come here are as colorful as their tents. For 3 days, we listened to their stories.
episode.subtitle: Starlit Tales from a Nagano Tent Village
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: It's midwinter at Tsugaru Strait, where a huge ferry connects the 120 kilometers between Aomori Prefecture and Hakodate, Hokkaido Prefecture. With showers, a game center and even suite rooms with beds, the spacious ferry can carry 600 passengers. At the end of each year, crowds of people head back to their hometowns on this boat. From a father living away from his family for work, to a couple excited about their new life together, everyone has a different reason for crossing the strait. We spend 3 days traveling between Aomori and Hakodate, and take a look at the stories of the people we meet.
episode.description: At the end of each year, crowds of people head home on a ferry crossing the Tsugaru Strait between Aomori Prefecture and Hokkaido. Over 3 days, we take a look at the stories of these ferry passengers.
episode.subtitle: Heading Home on the Strait Ferry
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: Located near Narita International Airport, Sakuranoyama Park offers visitors close-up views of planes arriving at and taking off from this major gateway to Japan. At times, several hundred people visit the park each day to catch awe-inspiring glimpses of huge aircraft flying overhead. Among the visitors were avid photographers, an elderly man who has never been on a plane, and a man fondly recalling the days when he flew all over the country on business trips. People at the park superimpose their own lives and dreams on the planes flying to distant corners of the world. For 3 days in early spring, a season for new beginnings, we listened to the stories of park visitors gazing at the planes up in the sky.
episode.description: As aircraft arrive at and depart Narita Airport in Japan, visitors to a nearby park watch on and long to be onboard. For 3 days, we spoke to people enchanted by the thrill of seeing planes up close.
episode.subtitle: A Park Where Dreams Take Wing
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: It is 780 meters long, dead straight and has few distinguishing features, but the undersea pedestrian tunnel running 60 meters underneath the Kanmon Straits in southwestern Japan attracts a steady stream of visitors. Many people use the tunnel to travel between Fukuoka Pref. and Yamaguchi Pref., but others have different purposes in mind. The visitors are diverse: from a woman in her 20's who brought her boyfriend to the tunnel that is filled with childhood memories, a man who comes to secretly train for a marathon, to a woman who walks there every week with old friends no matter how busy she is. What draws them to this nondescript tunnel that remains unchanged, day after day? We spend 3 days looking at who walks through this underground passage.
episode.description: Why do so many people visit a straight, 780-meter undersea tunnel with no view? For 3 days, we talked to people passing through this tunnel linking Fukuoka Pref. and Yamaguchi Pref. in western Japan.
episode.subtitle: The Sight Beyond the Undersea Tunnel
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: In a quiet mountain town in Kumamoto Prefecture, there's a flight of 3,333 stone steps. Measuring 2.1 kilometers, it's the longest in Japan and takes the average adult about 90 minutes to climb. The steps attract people who want to put themselves through a strenuous challenge for various reasons. One group of university students makes the climb knowing they will go their separate ways after graduation. An elderly beautician takes on the steps with apprentices who are like sons to him. Some visitors go up and down several times a day. With anguished looks and trembling legs, they test their limits. We spent 3 days meeting people going up and down the 3,333 steps.
episode.description: A flight of 3,333 stone steps in Kumamoto attracts people looking to put themselves through a strenuous challenge. We spent 3 days learning what makes them tackle Japan's longest flight of steps.
episode.subtitle: 3333 Stones: Japan's Longest Flight of Steps
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: If you start with a charm that supposedly brings good luck and offer to barter it with passersby on a bridge in Osaka Prefecture's Dotonbori district, what sort of trades will happen and people will you meet? For 3 days, we put this question to the test. The people who swapped items with us included a Frenchman who fell in love with Osaka and decided to live there, a women's soccer team visiting the city on a university graduation trip, and an elementary school student traveling with his father after participating in a national karate tournament. Through a series of trades, a connection gradually forms among strangers who otherwise would have no link with each other. When 72 hours are up, what has the "bringer of good luck" turned into?
episode.description: Starting with a charm that supposedly brings good luck, we make a series of successive trades with random passersby in Osaka Prefecture, Japan. Over 3 days, who will barter - and what will they offer?
episode.subtitle: A Barter Chain in Osaka
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: This episode focuses on a small real estate agency near Fukuoka Prefecture's Nakasu entertainment district, the biggest in Kyushu. Despite being tucked away on the third floor of a multitenant building and displaying no signage, this agency receives a steady stream of customers who have seen its online listings. This agency offers everything from dirt-cheap apartments where monthly rent costs less than 20,000 yen (about US $180) to commercial properties seeking new tenants. The growing range of properties handled by this real estate agency reflects the recent increase in Fukuoka's population. Moving to a new apartment or home can herald the start of a new chapter in life. What sort of people come to this real estate agency, and why do they want to rent a place?
episode.description: The customers and properties of a real estate agency in Fukuoka Prefecture are becoming diverse. For 3 days, we spoke to people seeking a new home in this fast-growing city in western Japan.
episode.subtitle: A Realtor in Fukuoka: Opening the Door to New Lives
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: A gym in a residential area of Tokyo offers classes for a slightly unusual activity where going backward is actually a sign of progress - doing backflips. These lessons are becoming increasingly popular among children, housewives, and company employees who drop by to master their technique after work. Among the people at this gym are a man in his 40's who has long admired Jackie Chan and a young woman who hopes doing backflips might give her cosplay photos a stylish edge. For 3 days, we spoke to people determined to find out if doing a complete backflip will also help their lives take a turn for the better.
episode.description: Could backflip lessons help your life take a turn for the better? For 3 days, we asked people attending classes at a small Tokyo gymnasium about what drives them to master this unusual activity.
episode.subtitle: Flipping Backward, Looking Forward
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: Runners have 72 hours to complete a 400-km "Survival Run" around the main island of Okinawa Prefecture, southern Japan. The 68 participants from across Japan complain that the race is exhausting and torturous, yet they continue to push themselves, day and night. Some say that running allows them to forget all their worries and stress, others say they enjoy increasing their distance. We spent 3 days chasing after them to find out what motivates them to continue running.
episode.description: In a 400K race in Okinawa Pref., participants keep running day and night to finish within the 72-hour time limit. We chased after them to find out why they push themselves to the brink of exhaustion.
episode.subtitle: A 400K "Survival Run" in Okinawa
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: A store in Akihabara, Japan's biggest electronics town, sells over 100,000 electronics parts, including resistors, capacitors and circuit boards. Around 1,000 people come to the store every day, from professional engineers to people who like to build their own electronics for fun. Among the people we meet are a musician who makes his own effects units; a graduate student who makes drones to take a break from job hunting; and a man whose hobby of fixing car audio systems has turned into a job. For 3 days, we peeked inside the store to find out what it is people come to buy and what they hope to create with it.
episode.description: In Akihabara, Japan's biggest electronics town, one store is famous for the wide range of electronics parts they carry - over 100,000 of them. What do people buy and what do they hope to make with it?
episode.subtitle: Akihabara: Infatuated with Electronics
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: The Great East Japan Earthquake and the ensuing Fukushima nuclear disaster in 2011 forced all the residents of Namie Town to evacuate. When the evacuation order was partially lifted in 2017, some residents began returning to their hometown. In the summer of 2019, a large supermarket opened its doors to eager shoppers. In this episode, we spent 3 days at the supermarket during the busiest time of the year - around New Year's - and asked customers how their lives have changed since the disaster, and how they will be spending the holidays, 9 years on.
episode.description: The Fukushima nuke disaster in 2011 forced Namie's residents to evacuate. Some have since returned, and a large supermarket opened recently. We asked shoppers how their lives have changed, 9 years on.
episode.subtitle: Home for the Holidays: A Supermarket in Fukushima
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: Every winter, anglers from across the country flock to one of Japan's most popular surf spots - Ishizakihama, in Miyazaki Prefecture, southwestern Japan. They all come in the hopes of catching the mulloway, a fish that approaches the shore around this time of year and can measure well over a meter in length. However, the chances of catching one is said to be as slim as winning the lottery. For 3 days, we spoke to the avid anglers who make every effort to capture these elusive creatures, and forge new friendships in the process.
episode.description: Every winter, avid anglers flock to a beach in southwestern Japan to catch mulloway, a fish that can grow to more than a meter long. Will any of them capture these elusive giants within 72 hours?
episode.subtitle: Big Fish, Big Dreams
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: 2 brothers in their 70's operate this unpretentious street stall that has only 1 item on the menu - coffee. The stall is set up each evening in Ashikaga City, Tochigi Prefecture, and has been a popular haunt for locals and visitors for almost half a century. Among the customers we met were: a successful psychiatrist who runs several hospitals; a company employee who always ends his week here; and a man who has been coming here since he was a little boy. For 3 days, we asked the customers about what makes this stall so special, and why they keep coming back.
episode.description: An evening street stall in Tochigi Prefecture, Japan, that sells only cups of coffee has stayed in business for nearly 50 years. For 3 days, we explored how this stall keeps its customers coming back.
episode.subtitle: Spilling the Beans at a Coffee Stall
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: For junior high or high school graduates, or drop-outs struggling to find their place in society, landing a well-paid, steady job can be almost impossible. But one training center in Tokyo teaches these disaffected youngsters practical skills during a six-month internship and transforms them into workers that companies need. About 400 people have completed this program at the center, and many of them have found excellent jobs at major IT firms and other companies. For 3 days, we closely watched the youngsters determined to turn their lives around and start climbing the career ladder.
episode.description: A training center in Tokyo helps teens who once went off the rails acquire the skills -and attitude - needed to find steady jobs. For 3 days, we followed the youngsters turning their lives around.
episode.subtitle: From Gang Ties to Business Suits
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: Every autumn, people from across Japan flock to a large observation area about 1,600 meters above sea level in the mountainous village of Achi, Nagano Prefecture. The picture-postcard views include forests of vibrant autumn leaves, starry skies and a sea of clouds. Many visitors arrive in the wee hours so they can reach the summit and watch the morning sunrise above the horizon - often making a wish as the new day dawns. For 3 days, we asked people why they come here and what is going through their minds as they soak up the views.
episode.description: Autumn-colored forests and stunning sunrises attract visitors from across Japan to an observation area in the mountains of Nagano. But for some, there is more than just natural beauty to discover.
episode.subtitle: Mountain Views, Life Insights
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: Tokyo Freight Terminal is Japan's largest distribution hub, with goods from across the nation arriving and being shipped out 24 hours a day. Train drivers, engineers, truck drivers and forklift operators are among the army of workers who keep this vital facility running smoothly. The volume of freight shipped by rail in Japan is growing annually due to the rise in online shopping and a shortage of truck drivers. For 3 days, we spoke to the men and women making sure these cargoes reach their destinations - safely and on time.
episode.description: Trains and trucks stream through Tokyo Freight Terminal, Japan's largest distribution hub, around the clock. For 3 days, we spoke to the workers who keep this vital facility up and running.
episode.subtitle: Inside Japan's Largest Freight Terminal
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: In this episode, the stage is a low-budget wedding hall in Tokyo, where 30-40 couples shuffle through every day for affordable, small-scale, short notice wedding arrangements. For many of the couples, the simple weddings are a display of best effort in the face of the demands of work and family. Some skip the ceremony altogether, opting to just have pictures taken to commemorate a turning point in their lives. For all the couples, the weddings represent a profound triumph over adversity, and celebration of a new life together. People from all walks of life, and their small wedding stories.
episode.description: A wedding hall in Tokyo offers affordable, small-scale ceremonies. People from all walks of life shuffle through every day for a consultation. We asked them about their small wedding story.
episode.subtitle: Small Wedding Stories
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: A road near Tokyo's Roppongi district is an oasis for taxi drivers who are allowed to park here for as long as they like. There, the drivers can relax, eat and even sleep on a break. As the coronavirus pandemic rumbles on, how do drivers feel about their jobs? The drivers we met included one who started this career after the pandemic erupted, one thinking of quitting because his income has plunged and another who cannot quit because he has a family to support. For 3 days, we asked drivers who parked along this road about their job and what the future holds.
episode.description: How has the coronavirus pandemic hit taxi drivers? What are they thinking as they drive the streets of Tokyo? For 3 days, we spoke to drivers relaxing along a street, which they call their "oasis."
episode.subtitle: Tokyo Taxi Oasis
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: The closure of Tokyo's Toshimaen amusement park in August 2020 marked the end of an era. For decades, El Dorado, the park's wooden carousel, was a popular attraction with visitors young and old. In the days before the park closed, visitors flocked to the carousel for a final ride, including an elderly couple who came on dates here before they married; a young man reminiscing about happier times with his family; and a woman who wants her late mother to see that she is back on her feet. For 3 days, we asked why this ride held such a special place in the hearts of so many people.
episode.description: The closure of Tokyo's Toshimaen amusement park marked the end of an era. For 3 days before the park closed, we asked visitors taking a final ride on its iconic wooden carousel why it was so special.
episode.subtitle: Adios, El Dorado Carousel!
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: As many people have spent more time at home during the coronavirus pandemic, gardening has become a popular hobby. Tokyo's garden megastore with over 100,000 varieties of plants is the go-to place for people wanting flowers, vegetables, bonsai trees or rare shrubs. The center's customers include a man inspired by a cactus' power to survive, a woman who buys weakened plants so she can help them recover and a woman who feels most relaxed when she tends to her plants. For 3 days, we asked what plants mean to them.
episode.description: A garden megastore in Tokyo has been a magnet for people who have taken up gardening while spending more time at home during the coronavirus pandemic. For 3 days, we asked what plants mean to them.
episode.subtitle: Seeds of Happiness at a Tokyo Garden Center
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: A Tokyo store selling cheap, good-quality kitchen equipment is a boon for restaurant owners, especially during the coronavirus pandemic. The store sells over 9,000 kinds of products, ranging from fridges to pots and pans to cutlery. Among customers we met were an owner of a Japanese-style bar who started meal deliveries; and a couple opening their dream caf√©. The store also receives a steady stream of requests to buy equipment from restaurants that have shut their doors. For 3 days, we asked operators who shop here about what's on their minds as they search for their new equipment.
episode.description: A Tokyo store selling mainly used kitchen equipment is a boon for restaurant owners reeling from the coronavirus pandemic or opening a new business. For 3 days, we asked what is on their minds.
episode.subtitle: Giving Kitchen Equipment New Homes
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: It's small and has only a few large animals, but a hilltop zoological park in Kawasaki, Kanagawa Prefecture, has captured the heart of locals for decades. It is home to about 60 different species and is frequented by many, especially since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic which has made it difficult to travel far. Among the visitors to this free admission zoo are people on family outings; a woman who comes on various milestones in her life; and a young couple who come at night to find nocturnal creatures in the park. For 3 days, we asked visitors why this seemingly ordinary zoo has become a special place for so many people.
episode.description: It's small and has only a few large animals, but a zoo in a residential area of Kawasaki, Japan, has captured the heart of locals for decades. For 3 days, we asked visitors why this zoo is so special.
episode.subtitle: The Zoo on a Hill
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: With over 40 kinds of handmade sandwiches including egg, mince cutlet and even fruit available, it could be the wide selection that draws customers to this small shop near Sapporo's Susukino entertainment district. However, this shop has another major attraction: it is open 24 hours a day. Among the customers we met, include a female owner of a nearby bar; a mother preparing breakfast for her family at 4 AM; and a nightclub host needing a snack before work. For 3 days, we spoke to the customers dropping by this shop that never sleeps.
episode.description: Many businesses cut their operating hours due to Covid-19, but one shop in Sapporo selling more than 40 kinds of sandwiches still operates around the clock. For 3 days, we spoke to its customers.
episode.subtitle: Sapporo Born and Bread: A 24-Hour Sandwich Shop
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: A major furniture outlet store in Chiba Prefecture boasts a stock of roughly 1,400 items from beds, sofas to tables. Customers are increasing since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic as people are staying in more and seeking to make their homes more comfortable. Among the customers we met were a man searching for a dining table hoping to spend quality time with his family, and a woman who is replacing all her furniture to surround herself with only the things she loves. The choices they make tell us something about who they are, and the changes and challenges they face in life. How do they picture their future? For 3 days, we listened to their stories.
episode.description: Customers are increasing at this major furniture outlet store, as more people seek to improve their homes during the coronavirus pandemic. For 3 days, we asked customers about their ideal lifestyle.
episode.subtitle: Opening New Doors at a Furniture Outlet Store
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: The 70-kilometer Shimanami Kaido cycling route, which links Honshu and Shikoku via a chain of bridges and islands, is a magnet for cyclists from across Japan - and even further afield. Among the people we met pedaling along this route were a father and son who come every year; a farmer reliving his youthful days on 2 wheels; and a middle-aged couple now able to spend more time together. Why is this route so special to them? For 3 days, we spoke to cyclists riding the Shimanami Kaido, come rain or shine.
episode.description: Shimanami Kaido is considered a "sacred" cycling route by riders in Japan. Why is this 70-kilometer route so special to them? For 3 days, we pedaled along with cyclists of all abilities to find out.
episode.subtitle: Shimanami Kaido: A Ride Along Life's Cycle
episode.title: Document 72 Hours

episode.content: Tanga Market, a century-old market of 120 shops in western Japan, is known as the "kitchen of Kitakyushu." Although the market will soon be redeveloped, its old-fashioned charm keeps pulling in shoppers. Among the customers there were a man who feels at home at the market, even if he does not buy anything; an elderly woman grumbling about having to cook her son's meals; and a young couple bewitched by the variety of foods sold there. For 3 days in late December, we explored why this market remains so popular.
episode.description: The 120 shop owners at century-old Tanga Market in western Japan insist on service with a personal touch. For 3 days in December, we asked people at the "kitchen of Kitakyushu" what makes it special.
episode.subtitle: Tanga: The Market With a Big Heart
episode.title: Document 72 Hours
